            <div class="c-feature-hd">
                <h1 class="c-hdgSans c-hdgSans_2 c-mix-hdgSans_inline">
                    The Glass Essay
                </h1>
                            </div>

            <div class="c-feature-sub c-feature-sub_vast">
                                                    <div>
                        <span class="c-txt c-txt_attribution">
                            By <a href="https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poets/anne-carson">Anne Carson</a>
                        </span>
                    </div>
                
                                                                
                            </div>

            

            <div class="c-feature-bd">
                <div class="o-poem " data-view="PoemView">
                    
                    
                    <div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">I<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I can hear little clicks inside my dream.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Night drips its silver tap<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> down the back.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> At 4 <small>A.M.</small> I wake. Thinking<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> of the man who<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> left in September.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> His name was Law.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> My face in the bathroom mirror<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> has white streaks down it.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I rinse the face and return to bed.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Tomorrow I am going to visit my mother.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> SHE<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> She lives on a moor in the north.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> She lives alone.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Spring opens like a blade there.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I travel all day on trains and bring a lot of books—<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> some for my mother, some for me<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> including <em>The Collected Works Of Emily Brontë</em>.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> This is my favourite author.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Also my main fear, which I mean to confront.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Whenever I visit my mother<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I feel I am turning into Emily Brontë,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> my lonely life around me like a moor,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> my ungainly body stumping over the mud flats with a look of transformation<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> that dies when I come in the kitchen door.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> What meat is it, Emily, we need?<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> THREE<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Three silent women at the kitchen table.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> My mother’s kitchen is dark and small but out the window<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> there is the moor, paralyzed with ice.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> It extends as far as the eye can see<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> over flat miles to a solid unlit white sky.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Mother and I are chewing lettuce carefully.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> The kitchen wall clock emits a ragged low buzz that jumps<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> once a minute over the twelve.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I have Emily p. 216 propped open on the sugarbowl<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> but am covertly watching my mother.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> A thousand questions hit my eyes from the inside.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> My mother is studying her lettuce.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I turn to p. 217.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> “In my flight through the kitchen I knocked over Hareton<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> who was hanging a litter of puppies<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> from a chairback in the doorway. . . .”<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> It is as if we have all been lowered into an atmosphere of glass.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Now and then a remark trails through the glass.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Taxes on the back lot. Not a good melon,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> too early for melons.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Hairdresser in town found God, closes shop every Tuesday.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Mice in the teatowel drawer again.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Little pellets. Chew off<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> the corners of the napkins, if they knew<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> what paper napkins cost nowadays.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Rain tonight.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Rain tomorrow.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> That volcano in the Philippines at it again. What’s her name<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Anderson died no not Shirley<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> the opera singer. Negress.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Cancer.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Not eating your garnish, you don’t like pimento?<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Out the window I can see dead leaves ticking over the flatland<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and dregs of snow scarred by pine filth.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> At the middle of the moor<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> where the ground goes down into a depression,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> the ice has begun to unclench.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Black open water comes<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> curdling up like anger. My mother speaks suddenly.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> That psychotherapy’s not doing you much good is it?<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> You aren’t getting over him.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> My mother has a way of summing things up.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> She never liked Law much<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> but she liked the idea of me having a man and getting on with life.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Well he’s a taker and you’re a giver I hope it works out,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> was all she said after she met him.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Give and take were just words to me<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> at the time. I had not been in love before.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> It was like a wheel rolling downhill.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> But early this morning while mother slept<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and I was downstairs reading the part in <em>Wuthering Heights</em><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> where Heathcliff clings at the lattice in the storm sobbing<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Come in! Come in! to the ghost of his heart’s darling,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I fell on my knees on the rug and sobbed too.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> She knows how to hang puppies,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> that Emily.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> It isn’t like taking an aspirin you know, I answer feebly.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Dr. Haw says grief is a long process.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> She frowns. What does it accomplish<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> all that raking up the past?<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Oh—I spread my hands—<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I prevail! I look her in the eye.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> She grins. Yes you do.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> WHACHER<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Whacher,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Emily’s habitual spelling of this word,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> has caused confusion.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> For example<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> in the first line of the poem printed <em>Tell me, whether, is it winter</em>?<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> in the Shakespeare Head edition.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> But whacher is what she wrote.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Whacher is what she was.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> She whached God and humans and moor wind and open night.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> She whached eyes, stars, inside, outside, actual weather.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> She whached the bars of time, which broke.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> She whached the poor core of the world,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> wide open.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> To be a whacher is not a choice.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> There is nowhere to get away from it,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> no ledge to climb up to—like a swimmer<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> who walks out of the water at sunset<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> shaking the drops off, it just flies open.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> To be a whacher is not in itself sad or happy,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> although she uses these words in her verse<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> as she uses the emotions of sexual union in her novel,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> grazing with euphemism the work of whaching.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> But it has no name.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> It is transparent.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Sometimes she calls it Thou.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> “Emily is in the parlour brushing the carpet,”<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> records Charlotte in 1828.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Unsociable even at home<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and unable to meet the eyes of strangers when she ventured out,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Emily made her awkward way<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> across days and years whose bareness appalls her biographers.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> This sad stunted life, says one.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Uninteresting, unremarkable, wracked by disappointment<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and despair, says another.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> She could have been a great navigator if she’d been male,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> suggests a third. Meanwhile<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Emily continued to brush into the carpet the question,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Why cast the world away.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> For someone hooked up to Thou,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> the world may have seemed a kind of half-finished sentence.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> But in between the neighbour who recalls her<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> coming in from a walk on the moors<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> with her face “lit up by a divine light”<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and the sister who tells us<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Emily never made a friend in her life,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> is a space where the little raw soul<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> slips through.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> It goes skimming the deep keel like a storm petrel,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> out of sight.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> The little raw soul was caught by no one.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> She didn’t have friends, children, sex, religion, marriage, success, a salary<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> or a fear of death. She worked<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> in total six months of her life (at a school in Halifax)<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and died on the sofa at home at 2 P.M. on a winter afternoon<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> in her thirty-first year. She spent<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> most of the hours of her life brushing the carpet,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> walking the moor<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> or whaching. She says<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> it gave her peace.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> “All tight and right in which condition it is to be hoped we shall all be this   <br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">     day 4 years,”<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> she wrote in her Diary Paper of 1837.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Yet her poetry from beginning to end is concerned with prisons,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> vaults, cages, bars, curbs, bits, bolts, fetters,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> locked windows, narrow frames, aching walls.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> “Why all the fuss?” asks one critic.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> “She wanted liberty. Well didn’t she have it?<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> A reasonably satisfactory homelife,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> a most satisfactory dreamlife—why all this beating of wings?<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> What was this cage, invisible to us,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> which she felt herself to be confined in?”<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Well there are many ways of being held prisoner,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I am thinking as I stride over the moor.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> As a rule after lunch mother has a nap<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and I go out to walk.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> The bare blue trees and bleached wooden sky of April<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> carve into me with knives of light.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Something inside it reminds me of childhood—<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> it is the light of the stalled time after lunch<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> when clocks tick<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and hearts shut<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and fathers leave to go back to work<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and mothers stand at the kitchen sink pondering<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> something they never tell.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> You remember too much,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> my mother said to me recently.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Why hold onto all that? And I said,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Where can I put it down?<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> She shifted to a question about airports.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Crops of ice are changing to mud all around me<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> as I push on across the moor<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> warmed by drifts from the pale blue sun.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> On the edge of the moor our pines<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> dip and coast in breezes<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> from somewhere else.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Perhaps the hardest thing about losing a lover is<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> to watch the year repeat its days.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> It is as if I could dip my hand down<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> into time and scoop up<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> blue and green lozenges of April heat<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> a year ago in another country.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I can feel that other day running underneath this one<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> like an old videotape—here we go fast around the last corner<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> up the hill to his house, shadows<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> of limes and roses blowing in the car window<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and music spraying from the radio and him<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> singing and touching my left hand to his lips.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Law lived in a high blue room from which he could see the sea.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Time in its transparent loops as it passes beneath me now<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> still carries the sound of the telephone in that room<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and traffic far off and doves under the window<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> chuckling coolly and his voice saying,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> You beauty. I can feel that beauty’s<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> heart beating inside mine as she presses into his arms in the high blue room—<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> No, I say aloud. I force my arms down<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> through air which is suddenly cold and heavy as water<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and the videotape jerks to a halt<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> like a glass slide under a drop of blood.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I stop and turn and stand into the wind,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> which now plunges towards me over the moor.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> When Law left I felt so bad I thought I would die.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> This is not uncommon.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I took up the practice of meditation.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Each morning I sat on the floor in front of my sofa<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and chanted bits of old Latin prayers.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><em>De profundis clamavi ad te Domine</em>.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Each morning a vision came to me.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Gradually I understood that these were naked glimpses of my soul.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I called them Nudes.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Nude #1. Woman alone on a hill.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> She stands into the wind.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> It is a hard wind slanting from the north.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Long flaps and shreds of flesh rip off the woman’s body and lift<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and blow away on the wind, leaving<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> an exposed column of nerve and blood and muscle<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> calling mutely through lipless mouth.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> It pains me to record this,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I am not a melodramatic person.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> But soul is “hewn in a wild workshop”<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> as Charlotte Brontë says of <em>Wuthering Heights</em>.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Charlotte’s preface to <em>Wuthering Heights</em> is a publicist’s masterpiece.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Like someone carefully not looking at a scorpion<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> crouched on the arm of the sofa Charlotte<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> talks firmly and calmly<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> about the other furniture of Emily’s workshop—about<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> the inexorable spirit (“stronger than a man, simpler than a child”),<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> the cruel illness (“pain no words can render”),<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> the autonomous end (“she sank rapidly, she made haste to leave us”)<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and about Emily’s total subjection<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> to a creative project she could neither understand nor control,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and for which she deserves no more praise nor blame<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> than if she had opened her mouth<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> “to breathe lightning.” The scorpion is inching down<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> the arm of the sofa while Charlotte<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> continues to speak helpfully about lightning<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and other weather we may expect to experience<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> when we enter Emily’s electrical atmosphere.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> It is “a horror of great darkness” that awaits us there<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> but Emily is not responsible. Emily was in the grip.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> “Having formed these beings she did not know what she had done,”<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> says Charlotte (of Heathcliff and Earnshaw and Catherine).<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Well there are many ways of being held prisoner.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> The scorpion takes a light spring and lands on our left knee<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> as Charlotte concludes, “On herself she had no pity.”<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Pitiless too are the Heights, which Emily called Wuthering<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> because of their “bracing ventilation”<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and “a north wind over the edge.”<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Whaching a north wind grind the moor<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> that surrounded her father’s house on every side,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> formed of a kind of rock called millstone grit,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> taught Emily all she knew about love and its necessities—<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> an angry education that shapes the way her characters<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> use one another. “My love for Heathcliff,” says Catherine,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> “resembles the eternal rocks beneath<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> a source of little visible delight, but necessary.”<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Necessary? I notice the sun has dimmed<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and the afternoon air sharpening.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I turn and start to recross the moor towards home.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> What are the imperatives<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> that hold people like Catherine and Heathcliff<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> together and apart, like pores blown into hot rock<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and then stranded out of reach<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> of one another when it hardens? What kind of necessity is that?<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> The last time I saw Law was a black night in September.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Autumn had begun,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> my knees were cold inside my clothes.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> A chill fragment of moon rose.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> He stood in my living room and spoke<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> without looking at me. Not enough spin on it,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> he said of our five years of love.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Inside my chest I felt my heart snap into two pieces<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> which floated apart. By now I was so cold<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> it was like burning. I put out my hand<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> to touch his. He moved back.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I don’t want to be sexual with you, he said. Everything gets crazy.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> But now he was looking at me.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Yes, I said as I began to remove my clothes.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Everything gets crazy. When nude<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I turned my back because he likes the back.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> He moved onto me.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Everything I know about love and its necessities<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I learned in that one moment<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> when I found myself<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> thrusting my little burning red backside like a baboon<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> at a man who no longer cherished me.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> There was no area of my mind<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> not appalled by this action, no part of my body<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> that could have done otherwise.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> But to talk of mind and body begs the question.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Soul is the place,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> stretched like a surface of millstone grit between body and mind,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> where such necessity grinds itself out.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Soul is what I kept watch on all that night.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Law stayed with me.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> We lay on top of the covers as if it weren’t really a night of sleep and time,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> caressing and singing to one another in our made-up language<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> like the children we used to be.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> That was a night that centred Heaven and Hell,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> as Emily would say. We tried to fuck<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> but he remained limp, although happy. I came<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> again and again, each time accumulating lucidity,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> until at last I was floating high up near the ceiling looking down<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> on the two souls clasped there on the bed<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> with their mortal boundaries<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> visible around them like lines on a map.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I saw the lines harden.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> He left in the morning.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> It is very cold<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> walking into the long scraped April wind.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> At this time of year there is no sunset<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> just some movements inside the light and then a sinking away.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> KITCHEN<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Kitchen is quiet as a bone when I come in.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> No sound from the rest of the house.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I wait a moment<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> then open the fridge.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Brilliant as a spaceship it exhales cold confusion.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> My mother lives alone and eats little but her fridge is always crammed.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> After extracting the yogurt container<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> from beneath a wily arrangement of leftover blocks of Christmas cake<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> wrapped in foil and prescription medicine bottles<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I close the fridge door. Bluish dusk<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> fills the room like a sea slid back.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I lean against the sink.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> White foods taste best to me<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and I prefer to eat alone. I don’t know why.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Once I heard girls singing a May Day song that went:<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">                                  Violante in the pantry<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">                                  Gnawing at a mutton bone<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">                                  How she gnawed it<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">                                  How she clawed it<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">                                  When she felt herself alone.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Girls are cruelest to themselves.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Someone like Emily Brontë,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> who remained a girl all her life despite her body as a woman,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> had cruelty drifted up in all the cracks of her like spring snow.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> We can see her ridding herself of it at various times<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> with a gesture like she used to brush the carpet.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Reason with him and then whip him!<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> was her instruction (age six) to her father<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> regarding brother Branwell.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> And when she was 14 and bitten by a rabid dog she strode (they say)<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> into the kitchen and taking red hot tongs from the back of the stove applied<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> them directly to her arm.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Cauterization of Heathcliff took longer.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> More than thirty years in the time of the novel,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> from the April evening when he runs out the back door of the kitchen<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and vanishes over the moor<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> because he overheard half a sentence of Catherine’s<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> (“It would degrade me to marry Heathcliff”)<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> until the wild morning<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> when the servant finds him stark dead and grinning<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> on his rainsoaked bed upstairs in Wuthering Heights.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Heathcliff is a pain devil.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> If he had stayed in the kitchen<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> long enough to hear the other half of Catherine’s sentence<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> (“so he will never know how I love him”)<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Heathcliff would have been set free.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> But Emily knew how to catch a devil.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> She put into him in place of a soul<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> the constant cold departure of Catherine from his nervous system<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> every time he drew a breath or moved thought.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> She broke all his moments in half,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> with the kitchen door standing open.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I am not unfamiliar with this half-life.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> But there is more to it than that.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Heathcliff’s sexual despair<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> arose out of no such experience in the life of Emily Brontë,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> so far as we know. Her question,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> which concerns the years of inner cruelty that can twist a person into a pain<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">     devil,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> came to her in a kindly firelit kitchen<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> (“kichin” in Emily’s spelling) where she<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and Charlotte and Anne peeled potatoes together<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and made up stories with the old house dog Keeper at their feet.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> There is a fragment<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> of a poem she wrote in 1839<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> (about six years before <em>Wuthering Heights</em>) that says:<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">                             That iron man was born like me<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">                             And he was once an ardent boy:<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">                             He must have felt in infancy<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">                             The glory of a summer sky.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Who is the iron man?<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> My mother’s voice cuts across me,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> from the next room where she is lying on the sofa.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Is that you dear?<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Yes Ma.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Why don’t you turn on a light in there?<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Out the kitchen window I watch the steely April sun<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> jab its last cold yellow streaks<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> across a dirty silver sky.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Okay Ma. What’s for supper?<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> LIBERTY<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Liberty means different things to different people.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I have never liked lying in bed in the morning.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Law did.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> My mother does.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> But as soon as the morning light hits my eyes I want to be out in it—<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> moving along the moor<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> into the first blue currents and cold navigation of everything awake.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I hear my mother in the next room turn and sigh and sink deeper.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I peel the stale cage of sheets off my legs<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and I am free.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Out on the moor all is brilliant and hard after a night of frost.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> The light plunges straight up from the ice to a blue hole at the top of the sky.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Frozen mud crunches underfoot. The sound<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> startles me back into the dream I was having<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> this morning when I awoke,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> one of those nightlong sweet dreams of lying in Law’s<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> arms like a needle in water—it is a physical effort<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> to pull myself out of his white silk hands<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> as they slide down my dream hips—I<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> turn and face into the wind<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and begin to run.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Goblins, devils and death stream behind me.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> In the days and months after Law left<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I felt as if the sky was torn off my life.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I had no home in goodness anymore.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> To see the love between Law and me<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> turn into two animals gnawing and craving through one another<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> towards some other hunger was terrible.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Perhaps this is what people mean by original sin, I thought.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> But what love could be prior to it?<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> What is prior?<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> What is love?<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> My questions were not original.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Nor did I answer them.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Mornings when I meditated<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I was presented with a nude glimpse of my lone soul,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> not the complex mysteries of love and hate.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> But the Nudes are still as clear in my mind<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> as pieces of laundry that froze on the clothesline overnight.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> There were in all thirteen of them.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Nude #2. Woman caught in a cage of thorns.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Big glistening brown thorns with black stains on them<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> where she twists this way and that way<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> unable to stand upright.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Nude #3. Woman with a single great thorn implanted in her forehead.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> She grips it in both hands<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> endeavouring to wrench it out.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Nude #4. Woman on a blasted landscape<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> backlit in red like Hieronymus Bosch.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Covering her head and upper body is a hellish contraption<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> like the top half of a crab.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> With arms crossed as if pulling off a sweater<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> she works hard at dislodging the crab.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> It was about this time<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I began telling Dr. Haw<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> about the Nudes. She said,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> When you see these horrible images why do you stay with them?<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Why keep watching? Why not<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> go away? I was amazed.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Go away where? I said.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> This still seems to me a good question.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> But by now the day is wide open and a strange young April light<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> is filling the moor with gold milk.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I have reached the middle<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> where the ground goes down into a depression and fills with swampy water.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> It is frozen.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> A solid black pane of moor life caught in its own night attitudes.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Certain wild gold arrangements of weed are visible deep in the black.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Four naked alder trunks rise straight up from it<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and sway in the blue air. Each trunk<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> where it enters the ice radiates a map of silver pressures—<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> thousands of hair-thin cracks catching the white of the light<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> like a jailed face<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> catching grins through the bars.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Emily Brontë has a poem about a woman in jail who says<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">                 A messenger of Hope, comes every night to me<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">                 And offers, for short life, eternal Liberty.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I wonder what kind of Liberty this is.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Her critics and commentators say she means death<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> or a visionary experience that prefigures death.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> They understand her prison<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> as the limitations placed on a clergyman’s daughter<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> by nineteenth-century life in a remote parish on a cold moor<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> in the north of England.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> They grow impatient with the extreme terms in which she figures prison life.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> “In so much of Brontë’s work<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> the self-dramatising and posturing of these poems teeters<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> on the brink of a potentially bathetic melodrama,”<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> says one. Another<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> refers to “the cardboard sublime” of her caught world.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I stopped telling my psychotherapist about the Nudes<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> when I realized I had no way to answer her question,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Why keep watching?<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Some people watch, that’s all I can say.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> There is nowhere else to go,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> no ledge to climb up to.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Perhaps I can explain this to her if I wait for the right moment,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> as with a very difficult sister.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> “On that mind time and experience alone could work:<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> to the influence of other intellects it was not amenable,”<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> wrote Charlotte of Emily.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I wonder what kind of conversation these two had<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> over breakfast at the parsonage.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> “My sister Emily<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> was not a person of demonstrative character,” Charlotte emphasizes,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> “nor one on the recesses of whose mind and feelings,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> even those nearest and dearest to her could,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> with impunity, intrude unlicensed. . . .” Recesses were many.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> One autumn day in 1845 Charlotte<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> “accidentally lighted on a MS. volume of verse in my sister Emily’s   <br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">     handwriting.”<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> It was a small (4 x 6) notebook<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> with a dark red cover marked 6d.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and contained 44 poems in Emily’s minute hand.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Charlotte had known Emily wrote verse<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> but felt “more than surprise” at its quality.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> “Not at all like the poetry women generally write.”<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Further surprise awaited Charlotte when she read Emily’s novel,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> not least for its foul language.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> She gently probes this recess<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> in her Editor’s Preface to <em>Wuthering Heights</em>.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> “A large class of readers, likewise, will suffer greatly<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> from the introduction into the pages of this work<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> of words printed with all their letters,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> which it has become the custom to represent by the initial and final letter<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">     only—a blank<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> line filling the interval.”<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Well, there are different definitions of Liberty.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Love is freedom, Law was fond of saying.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I took this to be more a wish than a thought<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and changed the subject.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> But blank lines do not say nothing.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> As Charlotte puts it,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> “The practice of hinting by single letters those expletives<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> with which profane and violent persons are wont to garnish their discourse,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> strikes me as a proceeding which,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> however well meant, is weak and futile.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I cannot tell what good it does—what feeling it spares—<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> what horror it conceals.”<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I turn my steps and begin walking back over the moor<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> towards home and breakfast. It is a two-way traffic,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> the language of the unsaid. My favourite pages<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> of <em>The Collected Works Of Emily Brontë</em><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> are the notes at the back<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> recording small adjustments made by Charlotte<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> to the text of Emily’s verse,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> which Charlotte edited for publication after Emily’s death.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> “<em>Prison</em> for <em>strongest</em> [in Emily’s hand] altered to <em>lordly</em> by Charlotte.”<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> HERO<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I can tell by the way my mother chews her toast<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> whether she had a good night<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and is about to say a happy thing<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> or not.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Not.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> She puts her toast down on the side of her plate.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> You know you can pull the drapes in that room, she begins.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> This is a coded reference to one of our oldest arguments,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> from what I call The Rules Of Life series.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> My mother always closes her bedroom drapes tight before going to bed at night.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I open mine as wide as possible.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I like to see everything, I say.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> What’s there to see?<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Moon. Air. Sunrise.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> All that light on your face in the morning. Wakes you up.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I like to wake up.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> At this point the drapes argument has reached a delta<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and may advance along one of three channels.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> There is the What You Need Is A Good Night’s Sleep channel,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> the Stubborn As Your Father channel<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and random channel.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> More toast? I interpose strongly, pushing back my chair.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Those women! says my mother with an exasperated rasp.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Mother has chosen random channel.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Women?<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Complaining about rape all the time<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I see she is tapping one furious finger on yesterday’s newspaper<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> lying beside the grape jam.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> The front page has a small feature<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> about a rally for International Women’s Day—<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> have you had a look at the Sears Summer Catalogue?<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Nope.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Why, it’s a disgrace! Those bathing suits—<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> cut way up to here! (she points) No wonder!<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> You’re saying women deserve to get raped<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> because Sears bathing suit ads<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> have high-cut legs? Ma, are you serious?<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Well someone has to be responsible.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Why should women be responsible for male desire? My voice is high.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Oh I see you’re one of Them.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> One of Whom? My voice is very high. Mother vaults it.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> And whatever did you do with that little tank suit you had last year the green<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">     one?<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> It looked so smart on you.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> The frail fact drops on me from a great height<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> that my mother is afraid.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> She will be eighty years old this summer.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Her tiny sharp shoulders hunched in the blue bathrobe<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> make me think of Emily Brontë’s little merlin hawk Hero<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> that she fed bits of bacon at the kitchen table when Charlotte wasn‘t around.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> So Ma, we’ll go—I pop up the toaster<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and toss a hot slice of pumpernickel lightly across onto her plate—<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> visit Dad today? She eyes the kitchen clock with hostility.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Leave at eleven, home again by four? I continue.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> She is buttering her toast with jagged strokes.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Silence is assent in our code. I go into the next room to phone the taxi.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> My father lives in a hospital for patients who need chronic care<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> about 50 miles from here.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> He suffers from a kind of dementia<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> characterized by two sorts of pathological change<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> first recorded in 1907 by Alois Alzheimer.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> First, the presence in cerebral tissue<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> of a spherical formation known as neuritic plaque,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> consisting mainly of degenerating brain cells.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Second, neurofibrillary snarlings<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> in the cerebral cortex and in the hippocampus.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> There is no known cause or cure.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Mother visits him by taxi once a week<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> for the last five years.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Marriage is for better or for worse, she says,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> this is the worse.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> So about an hour later we are in the taxi<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> shooting along empty country roads towards town.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> The April light is clear as an alarm.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> As we pass them it gives a sudden sense of every object<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> existing in space on its own shadow.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I wish I could carry this clarity with me<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> into the hospital where distinctions tend to flatten and coalesce.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I wish I had been nicer to him before he got crazy.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> These are my two wishes.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> It is hard to find the beginning of dementia.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em;
