padding-left: 1em;"> I remember a night about ten years ago<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> when I was talking to him on the telephone.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> It was a Sunday night in winter.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I heard his sentences filling up with fear.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> He would start a sentence—about weather, lose his way, start another.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> It made me furious to hear him floundering—<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> my tall proud father, former World War II navigator!<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> It made me merciless.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I stood on the edge of the conversation,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> watching him thrash about for cues,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> offering none,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and it came to me like a slow avalanche<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> that he had no idea who he was talking to.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Much colder today I guess. . . .<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> his voice pressed into the silence and broke off,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> snow falling on it.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> There was a long pause while snow covered us both.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Well I won’t keep you,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> he said with sudden desperate cheer as if sighting land.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I’ll say goodnight now,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I won’t run up your bill. Goodbye.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Goodbye.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Goodbye. Who are you?<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I said into the dial tone.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> At the hospital we pass down long pink halls<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> through a door with a big window<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and a combination lock (5—25—3)<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> to the west wing, for chronic care patients.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Each wing has a name.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> The chronic wing is Our Golden Mile<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> although mother prefers to call it The Last Lap.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Father sits strapped in a chair which is tied to the wall<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> in a room of other tied people tilting at various angles.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> My father tilts least, I am proud of him.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Hi Dad how y’doing?<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> His face cracks open it could be a grin or rage<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and looking past me he issues a stream of vehemence at the air.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> My mother lays her hand on his.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Hello love, she says. He jerks his hand away. We sit.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Sunlight flocks through the room.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Mother begins to unpack from her handbag the things she has brought for him,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> grapes, arrowroot biscuits, humbugs.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> He is addressing strenuous remarks to someone in the air between us.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> He uses a language known only to himself,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> made of snarls and syllables and sudden wild appeals.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Once in a while some old formula floats up through the wash—<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> You don’t say! or Happy birthday to you!—<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> but no real sentence<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> for more than three years now.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I notice his front teeth are getting black.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I wonder how you clean the teeth of mad people.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> He always took good care of his teeth. My mother looks up.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> She and I often think two halves of one thought.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Do you remember that gold-plated toothpick<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> you sent him from Harrod’s the summer you were in London? she asks.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Yes I wonder what happened to it.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Must be in the bathroom somewhere.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> She is giving him grapes one by one.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> They keep rolling out of his huge stiff fingers.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> He used to be a big man, over six feet tall and strong,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> but since he came to hospital his body has shrunk to the merest bone house—<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> except the hands. The hands keep growing.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Each one now as big as a boot in Van Gogh,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> they go lumbering after the grapes in his lap.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> But now he turns to me with a rush of urgent syllables<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> that break off on a high note—he waits,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> staring into my face. That quizzical look.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> One eyebrow at an angle.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I have a photograph taped to my fridge at home.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> It shows his World War II air crew posing in front of the plane.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Hands firmly behind backs, legs wide apart,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> chins forward.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Dressed in the puffed flying suits<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> with a wide leather strap pulled tight through the crotch.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> They squint into the brilliant winter sun of 1942.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> It is dawn.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> They are leaving Dover for France.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> My father on the far left is the tallest airman,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> with his collar up,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> one eyebrow at an angle.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> The shadowless light makes him look immortal,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> for all the world like someone who will not weep again.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> He is still staring into my face.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Flaps down! I cry.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> His black grin flares once and goes out like a match.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> HOT<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Hot blue moonlight down the steep sky.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I wake too fast from a cellar of hanged puppies<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> with my eyes pouring into the dark.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Fumbling<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and slowly<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> consciousness replaces the bars.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Dreamtails and angry liquids<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> swim back down to the middle of me.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> It is generally anger dreams that occupy my nights now.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> This is not uncommon after loss of love—<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> blue and black and red blasting the crater open.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I am interested in anger.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I clamber along to find the source.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> My dream was of an old woman lying awake in bed.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> She controls the house by a system of light bulbs strung above her on wires.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Each wire has a little black switch.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> One by one the switches refuse to turn the bulbs on.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> She keeps switching and switching<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> in rising tides of very hot anger.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Then she creeps out of bed to peer through lattices<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> at the rooms of the rest of the house.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> The rooms are silent and brilliantly lit<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and full of huge furniture beneath which crouch<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> small creatures—not quite cats not quite rats<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> licking their narrow red jaws<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> under a load of time.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I want to be beautiful again, she whispers<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> but the great overlit rooms tick emptily<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> as a deserted oceanliner and now behind her in the dark<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> a rustling sound, comes—<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> My pajamas are soaked.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Anger travels through me, pushes aside everything else in my heart,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> pouring up the vents.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Every night I wake to this anger,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> the soaked bed,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> the hot pain box slamming me each way I move.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I want justice. Slam.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I want an explanation. Slam.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I want to curse the false friend who said I love you forever. Slam.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I reach up and switch on the bedside lamp. Night springs<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> out the window and is gone over the moor.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I lie listening to the light vibrate in my ears<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and thinking about curses.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Emily Brontë was good at cursing.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Falsity and bad love and the deadly pain of alteration are constant topics in<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">     her verse.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">                      Well, thou halt paid me back my love!<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">                      But if there be a God above<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">                      Whose arm is strong, whose word is true,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">                      This hell shall wring thy spirit too!<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> The curses are elaborate:<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">             There go, Deceiver, go! My hand is streaming wet;<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">             My heart’s blood flows to buy the blessing—To forget!<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">             Oh could that lost heart give back, back again to thine,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">             One tenth part of the pain that clouds my dark decline!<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> But they do not bring her peace:<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">        Vain words, vain frenzied thoughts! No ear can hear me call—<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">        Lost in the vacant air my frantic curses fall. . . .<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">        Unconquered in my soul the Tyrant rules me still—<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">        <em>Life</em> bows to my control, but <em>Love</em> I cannot kill!<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Her anger is a puzzle.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> It raises many questions in me,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> to see love treated with such cold and knowing contempt<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> by someone who rarely left home<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> “except to go to church or take a walk on the hills”<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> (Charlotte tells us) and who<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> had no more intercourse with Haworth folk<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> than “a nun has<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> of the country people who sometimes pass her convent gates.”<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> How did Emily come to lose faith in humans?<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> She admired their dialects, studied their genealogies,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> “but with them she rarely exchanged a word.”<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Her introvert nature shrank from shaking hands with someone she met on the moor.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> What did Emily know of lover’s lies or cursive human faith?<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Among her biographers<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> is one who conjectures she bore or aborted a child<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> during her six-month stay in Halifax,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> but there is no evidence at all for such an event<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and the more general consensus is that Emily did not touch a man in her 31<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">     years.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Banal sexism aside,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I find myself tempted<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> to read <em>Wuthering Heights</em> as one thick stacked act of revenge<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> for all that life withheld from Emily.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> But the poetry shows traces of a deeper explanation.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> As if anger could be a kind of vocation for some women.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> It is a chilly thought.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">                            <br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">                               The heart is dead since infancy.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">                               Unwept for let the body go.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Suddenly cold I reach down and pull the blanket back up to my chin.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> The vocation of anger is not mine.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I know my source.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> It is stunning, it is a moment like no other,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> when one’s lover comes in and says I do not love you anymore.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I switch off the lamp and lie on my back,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> thinking about Emily’s cold young soul.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Where does unbelief begin?<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> When I was young<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> there were degrees of certainty.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I could say, Yes I know that I have two hands.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Then one day I awakened on a planet of people whose hands occasionally   <br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">     disappear—<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> From the next room I hear my mother shift and sigh and settle<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> back down under the doorsill of sleep.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Out the window the moon is just a cold bit of silver gristle low on fading banks<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">     of sky.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">           Our guests are darkly lodged, I whispered, gazing through<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">           The vault . . .<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> THOU<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> The question I am left with is the question of her loneliness.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> And I prefer to put it off.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> It is morning.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Astonished light is washing over the moor from north to east.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I am walking into the light.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> One way to put off loneliness is to interpose God.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Emily had a relationship on this level with someone she calls Thou. She describes Thou as awake like herself all night<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and full of strange power.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Thou woos Emily with a voice that comes out of the night wind.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Thou and Emily influence one another in the darkness,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> playing near and far at once.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> She talks about a sweetness that “proved us one.”<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I am uneasy with the compensatory model of female religious experience and yet,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> there is no question,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> it would be sweet to have a friend to tell things to at night,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> without the terrible sex price to pay.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> This is a childish idea, I know.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> My education, I have to admit, has been gappy.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> The basic rules of male-female relations<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> were imparted atmospherically in our family,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> no direct speech allowed.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I remember one Sunday I was sitting in the backseat of the car.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Father in front.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> We were waiting in the driveway for mother,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> who came around the corner of the house<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and got into the passenger side of the car<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> dressed in a yellow Chanel suit and black high heels.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Father glanced sideways at her.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Showing a good bit of leg today Mother, he said<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> in a voice which I (age eleven) thought odd.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I stared at the back of her head waiting for what she would say.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Her answer would clear this up.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> But she just laughed a strange laugh with ropes all over it.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Later that summer I put this laugh together with another laugh<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I overheard as I was going upstairs.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> She was talking on the telephone in the kitchen.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Well a woman would be just as happy with a kiss on the cheek<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> most of the time but YOU KNOW MEN,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> she was saying. Laugh.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Not ropes, thorns.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I have arrived at the middle of the moor<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> where the ground goes down into a low swampy place.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> The swamp water is frozen solid.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Bits of gold weed<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> have etched themselves<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> on the underside of the ice like messages.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">                         I’ll come when thou art saddest,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">                         Laid alone in the darkened room;<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">                         When the mad day’s mirth has vanished,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">                         And the smile of joy is banished,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">                          I’ll come when the heart’s real feeling<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">                          Has entire, unbiased sway,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">                          And my influence o’er thee stealing<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">                          Grief deepening, joy congealing,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">                          Shall bear thy soul away.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">                          Listen! ’tis just the hour,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">                          The awful time for thee:<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">                          Dost thou not feel upon thy soul<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">                          A flood of strange sensations roll,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">                          Forerunners of a sterner power,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">                          Heralds of me?<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Very hard to read, the messages that pass<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> between Thou and Emily.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> In this poem she reverses their roles,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> speaking not as the victim but <em>to</em> the victim.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> It is chilling to watch Thou move upon thou,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> who lies alone in the dark waiting to be mastered.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> It is a shock to realize that this low, slow collusion<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> of master and victim within one voice<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> is a rationale<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> for the most awful loneliness of the poet’s hour.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> She has reversed the roles of thou and Thou<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> not as a display of power<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> but to force out of herself some pity<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> for this soul trapped in glass,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> which is her true creation.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Those nights lying alone<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> are not discontinuous with this cold hectic dawn.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> It is who I am.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Is it a vocation of anger?<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Why construe silence<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> as the Real Presence?<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Why stoop to kiss this doorstep?<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Why be unstrung and pounded flat and pine away<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> imagining someone vast to whom I may vent the swell of my soul?<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Emily was fond of Psalm 130.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> “My soul waiteth on Thou more than they that watch for the morning,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I say more than they that watch for the morning.”<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I like to believe that for her the act of watching provided a shelter,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> that her collusion with Thou gave ease to anger and desire:<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> ”In Thou they are quenched as a fire of thorns,“ says the psalmist.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> But for myself I do not believe this, I am not quenched—<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> with Thou or without Thou I find no shelter.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I am my own Nude.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> And Nudes have a difficult sexual destiny.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I have watched this destiny disclose itself<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> in its jerky passage from girl to woman to who I am now,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> from love to anger to this cold marrow,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> from fire to shelter to fire.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> What is the opposite of believing in Thou—<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> merely not believing in Thou? No. That is too simple.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> That is to prepare a misunderstanding.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I want to speak more clearly.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Perhaps the Nudes are the best way.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Nude #5. Deck of cards.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Each card is made of flesh.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> The living cards are days of a woman’s life.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I see a great silver needle go flashing right through the deck once from end to<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">     end.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Nude #6 I cannot remember.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Nude #7. White room whose walls,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> having neither planes nor curves nor angles,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> are composed of a continuous satiny white membrane<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> like the flesh of some interior organ of the moon.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> It is a living surface, almost wet.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Lucency breathes in and out.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Rainbows shudder across it.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> And around the walls of the room a voice goes whispering,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><em>Be very careful. Be very careful</em>.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Nude #8. Black disc on which the fires of all the winds<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> are attached in a row.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> A woman stands on the disc<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> amid the winds whose long yellow silk flames<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> flow and vibrate up through her.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Nude #9. Transparent loam.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Under the loam a woman has dug a long deep trench.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Into the trench she is placing small white forms, I don’t know what they are.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Nude #10. Green thorn of the world poking up<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> alive through the heart of a woman<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> who lies on her back on the ground.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> The thorn is exploding<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> its green blood above her in the air.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><em>Everything it is it has</em>, the voice says.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Nude #11. Ledge in outer space.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Space is bluish black and glossy as solid water<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and moving very fast in all directions,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> shrieking past the woman who stands pinned<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> to nothing by its pressure.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> She peers and glances for some way to go, trying to lift her hand but cannot.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Nude #12. Old pole in the wind.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Cold currents are streaming over it<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and pulling out<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> into ragged long horizontal black lines<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> some shreds of ribbon<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> attached to the pole.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I cannot see how they are attached—<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> notches? staples? nails? All of a sudden the wind changes<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and all the black shreds rise straight up in the air<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and tie themselves into knots,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> then untie and float down.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> The wind is gone.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> It waits.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> By this time, midway through winter,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I had become entirely fascinated with my spiritual melodrama.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Then it stopped.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Days passed, months passed and I saw nothing.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I continued to peer and glance, sitting on the rug in front of my sofa<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> in the curtainless morning<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> with my nerves open to the air like something skinned.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I saw nothing.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Outside the window spring storms came and went.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> April snow folded its huge white paws over doors and porches.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I watched a chunk of it lean over the roof and break off<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> and fall and I thought,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> How slow! as it glided soundlessly past,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> but still—nothing. No nudes.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> No Thou.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> A great icicle formed on the railing of my balcony<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> so I drew up close to the window and tried peering through the icicle,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> hoping to trick myself into some interior vision,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> but all I saw<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> was the man and woman in the room across the street<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> making their bed and laughing.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I stopped watching.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I forgot about Nudes.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I lived my life,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> which felt like a switched-off TV.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Something had gone through me and out and I could not own it.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> “No need now to tremble for the hard frost and the keen wind.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Emily does not feel them,”<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> wrote Charlotte the day after burying her sister.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Emily had shaken free.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> A soul can do that.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Whether it goes to join Thou and sit on the porch for all eternity<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> enjoying jokes and kisses and beautiful cold spring evenings,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> you and I will never know. But I can tell you what I saw.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Nude #13 arrived when I was not watching for it.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> It came at night.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> Very much like Nude #1.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> And yet utterly different.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I saw a high hill and on it a form shaped against hard air.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> It could have been just a pole with some old cloth attached,<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> but as I came closer<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> I saw it was a human body<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> trying to stand against winds so terrible that the flesh was blowing off the bones.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> And there was no pain.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> The wind<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> was cleansing the bones.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> They stood forth silver and necessary.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> It was not my body, not a woman’s body, it was the body of us all.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"> It walked out of the light.<br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;">  <br></div><div style="text-indent: -1em; padding-left: 1em;"><br></div>
                </div>
            </div>
        </div>
    </div>
